awd_titl_txt: A Comprehensive Model for Improving the Success of STEM Majors through the STEM Center
awd_abstract_narration:
In 2012, the "Engage to Excel" report from the President's Council of Advisors on Science and Technology (PCAST) declared a national need for an additional one million college graduates in STEM fields over the next decade. The 40% retention rate among STEM majors nationally presents a major hurdle to meeting this need. The goal of this project is to increase the number and quality of STEM graduates by adapting and combining three proven approaches. The first, aimed at students who intend to pursue STEM majors at the outset of their college careers, will prepare students for success in STEM coursework by creating community among participants; developing necessary reading, note-taking, and time-management skills; reinforcing fundamental concepts in mathematics; and helping students understand their individual approaches to effective learning. The second approach will expand the use of effective, evidence-based teaching methods across STEM disciplines. The third approach will engage students in research in a course early in their college careers. The project's components will form a comprehensive model for increasing the quality and quantity of STEM graduates that can be replicated and sustained across many institutions.

The STEM Center at Sam Houston State University will integrate and improve upon tested interventions for retaining students in STEM. Using methods and materials developed by the Charles A. Dana Center at the University of Texas at Austin, the project team will create an immersive summer experience for entering STEM majors, "Frameworks and Foundations," to focus on frameworks of field-specific skills for collegiate success and foundations of STEM content in mathematics, chemistry, and engineering technology. The STEM Center will broaden the use of Inquiry-Based Learning (IBL) practices and Process-Oriented Guided Inquiry Learning (POGIL) methods across STEM disciplines and degree programs. To specifically engage students in scientific practice, the project will embed a course-based undergraduate research experience (CURE) in the STEM curriculum. This new research-focused course, which students will take as soon as they complete their first-year STEM coursework, will quickly prepare them to conduct meaningful scientific research on an original topic developed by each student along with an identified faculty mentor. This course will particularly target transfer students and those from groups traditionally underrepresented in the sciences. Although the project will utilize proven practices, its innovation mainly lies in its comprehensive approach. The project evaluation will add to the body of knowledge about the effectiveness of the interventions and, especially, their integration in this model. Elements of the evaluation will include measures of retention, course completion, and graduation; comparison of students taking IBL and POGIL courses with respect to gains in critical thinking skills, argumentation skills, academic performance, etc.; comparison of students' performance across disciplines to identify transferability of skills; comparison of learning outcomes of students who complete the "Frameworks" and "Foundations" courses with learning outcomes of students who do not; and surveys of students in the modified learning environments to examine perceived differences in teaching and learning strategies.

por.por_cntn:
Since its inception, the STEM Center at Sam Houston State University (SHSU) has embarked on an ambitious mission to elevate STEM undergraduate education's standard and success rate. This comprehensive narrative outlines the remarkable achievements of the STEM Center's initiatives, highlighting their substantial impact on student performance, diversity, and the broader educational landscape.

From the beginning, the STEM Center has focused on enhancing student performance in STEM disciplines. A striking testament to this is the significant improvement in the pass rates of participants in the bridge courses, ranging from 70% to an impressive 86%. This leap in academic achievement underscores the effectiveness of the STEM Center's pedagogical strategies and its profound impact on students' academic journeys. The bridge courses, tailored to the needs of first-year STEM students, have become a cornerstone of the STEM Center's approach, blending rigorous academic preparation with practical skills essential for succeeding in STEM fields.

The expanding reach of these courses is another indicator of the program's success. Since 2018, the STEM Center has supported 295 students, reflecting a strong and growing interest in its offerings. This expansion is not just in numbers; it represents a commitment to enhancing STEM education quality and accessibility. The STEM Center's efforts to increase diversity have borne fruit, with the bridge courses attracting more students. This diversification mirrors SHSU's varied student body, signaling a move towards more inclusive and representative STEM education.

Despite the challenges posed by the transition to online learning, the STEM Center has shown remarkable resilience and adaptability. The enrollment and retention in bridge courses continued to climb, demonstrating the STEM Center's relevance and effectiveness in a rapidly changing educational environment. Developing remote learning strategies during 2020-2022 was a crucial adaptation, ensuring that students remained engaged and prepared for the academic year ahead.

The STEM Center's focus on math and chemistry, in particular, has yielded substantial benefits. Students participating in these bridge courses consistently outperformed their peers, highlighting the targeted courses' effectiveness in bolstering students' foundational knowledge in these critical subjects. This achievement directly results from the STEM Center's dedication to integrating research-based strategies into its curriculum. The evidence-based learning approaches employed have clearly paid dividends, as reflected in the enhanced academic preparedness and performance of the students.

The flexible and robust course design has been another key factor in the STEM Center's success. Employing a backward course design, the STEM Center has maintained a dynamic and responsive educational environment, capable of evolving to meet the changing needs of students and the STEM education landscape. This adaptability is a hallmark of the STEM Center's commitment to continuous improvement and excellence.

The feedback from students participating in the bridge courses further underscores the program's effectiveness. Students have reported a marked improvement in their preparation for academic challenges, development of study and communication skills, and a significant boost in confidence. The program's orientation towards career development and its focus on familiarizing students with university systems have been particularly well-received. Including guest speakers has provided valuable insights into potential STEM career paths, further enriching the students' learning experience.

In addition to these educational outcomes, the STEM Center has made significant strides in fostering a collaborative and innovative STEM education environment. The Be(e) STEM Symposium held on April 21, 2021, exemplifies this, creating a platform for networking and sharing cutting-edge STEM education strategies. The STEM Center's physical space, inaugurated in 2019, offers state-of-the-art learning and meeting environments, further cementing its role as a hub of STEM education excellence.

The formation of the STEM Center Advisory Board has been instrumental in enhancing collaboration among the STEM departments, ensuring a cohesive and integrated approach to STEM education. Moreover, the STEM Center's contributions to academic discourse are noteworthy, with 11 journal publications and nearly 30 conference presentations. These scholarly activities have elevated the STEM Center's profile and contributed significantly to the broader conversation on educational strategies and research in college-level education.

The STEM Center at SHSU has achieved its initial objectives and set a new benchmark for STEM education. Its comprehensive approach, combining enhanced student performance, increased diversity, and innovative teaching strategies, has proven to be a successful model with great promise for replication in similar institutions. The STEM Center's impact extends beyond SHSU, contributing to the broader goal of advancing STEM education nationally and globally.
